title: lower-case ar - not quite pirate material (but still British?)
content:
Circa 1983, and British in origin. I'm not finding much in terms of a match - and this is all the sample I have.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [oscar\_ar\_sample.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831054131/http:/typophile.com/files/oscar_ar_sample.jpg) | 41.93 KB |
author: idiotcountry

comments.content: You can try a **[Chalet Comprime (HongKong 1980)](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831054131/http:/www.findmyfont.com/index.php/fonts/font-preview?fset=House-Industries&ffam=ChaletComprime%20-%20HongKongEighty&fid=919578ab226ce5ec371006e9ac0e910d&fstyle=b&fsize=60&text=ar&fit=1)** by House Industries, probably a bit emboldened

Thanks. I did discover the similarity between that House font and the sample, but surely it was based on something else that was either Letraset or UK-based? I swear I have seen this font used elsewhere. Certainly on a UK record sleeve from the early 1980s (not where this sample originated from, unfortunately).

I wish [Bristish Inserat](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831054131/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/itfmecanorma/british-inserat) had a single storey /a... Very [Compacta](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831054131/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/compacta) BTW. An interesting alternative would be [Press Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831054131/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/press-gothic) which has a [single storey /a](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831054131/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/press-gothic/pro/glyphs.html#glyphs/404671/359). Alternative, no single storey /a though: [Fusion Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831054131/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/parachute/pf-fusion-sans-pro)

Ah, I would bet Press Gothic is the source. For the single story l/c 'a', you could decapitate a l/c 'd' and bob's yer uncle. Same with Compacta. Nice and thank you.

As an aside, I thought most type designers had un-natural affinities towards lower case 'a' and ampersands. Wouldn't take much effort to incorporate some crazy alternate glyphs in their digital work would it?
